Authors:
Paulina Janik, Magdalena Szczepaniak, Carlos Lado, Anna
Ronikier
Title:
Didymium pseudonivicola Â– a new myxomycete from the austral
Andes emerges from the broad-scale morphological and molecular analyses
of D. nivicola collections
Keywords:
Amoebozoa, distribution, Myxogastria, nivicolous species,
Physarales, SEM, taxonomy, 18S rRNA, EF1A, 1 new taxon
Abstract:
A new nivicolous myxomycete is described as a result of a
comprehensive study of Didymium nivicola collections from the entire
range of its occurrence. Statistical analysis of twelve morphological
characters, phylogenetic analyses of two molecular markers: partial
small ribosomal subunit (18S rDNA) and elongation factor 1-alpha gene
(EF1A), and delimitation method (Automatic Barcode Gap Diversity) have
been applied. A preliminary morphological analysis of D. nivicola
collections done within the present study prior to the statistical
analysis of morphological characters revealed high variability of South
American populations where four types of spore ornamentation were noted.
Results of molecular study and statistical analysis of morphological
characters, however, did not support the recognition of these four forms
but supported the distinction of two morphotypes. In consequence, two
species has been recognized: D. nivicola and the newly proposed D.
pseudonivicola. The new species, can be distinguished from D. nivicola
by distinctly larger, mostly plasmodiocarpic sporophores, which are
scattered to gregarious, by its paler spores and by paler, more delicate
and more elastic capillitium. Spore ornamentation of D. pseudonivicola
is uniform and can be described as distinctly spiny (pilate by SEM)
while those of D. nivicola is more variable, where spines (pilae by SEM)
are delicate, distinct or conspicuous. While D. nivicola is a species
distributed worldwide, D. pseudonivicola occurs only in the austral
Andes of Argentina and Chile.
